Posts.Content: Interesting to read this. Whilst I found my BCN very pleasant I only ever saw her three times and once was when I bumped into her in a corridor. I suspect she was very busy and as some people have said here others were in greater need.
Posts.Title: BCN

Posts.Content: Just wanting to send support. Sometimes if you are the person in the family whe helps everyone else it can be difficult to just take time out for yourself. It's always worrying waiting for consultations but I hope you can relax a bit and enjoy the support from the people here.
Posts.Title: Feeling Totally Demoralised!

Posts.Content: Hello Lee26 i can't comment on your question about double mastectomy and not taking Arimidex but I can comment on taking AIs. I take letrozole and have been on it now for six months. Any medication always gives a list of side effects but people are affected in different ways. I have had two issues with Letrozole. I had rather horrid hot flushes at first and that lasted maybe two months. Also I'm having short term memory problems with it. This might be age too! However, now I realise what's happening I keep a notebook. So I just wanted to say that not everyone has the side effects. Squeaky
Posts.Title: Can I avoid hormone therapy if I elect to have a double mastectomy...

Posts.Content: Lucy, the article that Dreamthief mentioned above is excellent and helps I think. I'm afraid that with cancer we all have to accept we have a 'new normal' and adapt accordingly. Sometimes it's scary but if we set goals like you have done then we can move forward. Thanks for posting you have made me think about new goals to set.
Posts.Title: Finding the uncertainty unbearable at times

Posts.Content: You are, indeed, a wonderful daughter in law not only because you are asking advice here but also because you are saying quite clearly to your step mum that there is no wrong decision and not putting pressure on her.  The stats and  charts are a little baffling and they are about your profile rather than about you and by the very nature of them are out of date already and things are getting better for us all the time. I am not quite in the same situation as your step mum. I am a little younger, nearly 65. When I talked to the oncologist she said for my profile it would be a 3% improvement and I didn't hesitate to say thanks but no thanks. She put me under no pressure at all. So I went on to radiotherapy. I think where it is clear cut that chemo would be beneficial the oncologist will offer it and you can of course refuse. Where we are borderline the oncologist will try to give us options and figures but leave the choice to us. Your last paragraph is very insightful. The thing is we dont know what is in front of us when we make choices. Please continue to support your step mum in whatever choice she makes. Squeaky
Posts.Title: Chemo Decisions

Posts.Content: I just wanted to send you good wishes in your role of supporting your mum just now. She will be grateful for your support. Although I have had to make some choices in treatment I didn't have to make the one your mum is faced with but I am sure that there will soon be more posts to help you and your mum.
Posts.Title: My mum is unsure what op to have

Posts.Content: I think that if, indeed, you are borderline for chemo the onc will give you good guidance. There are some people who will take any treatment and others who believe that a small percentage of advantage is not worth the possible side effects of chemo. I'm sure you will get good explanations and I hope it goes well.
Posts.Title: Questions for my oncology appointment!

Posts.Content: I have an annual check up due in early December. I know that I'm unusual in deciding not to have chemo but 4% just wasn't worth it for me. I was 64 at the time. For other reasons I made the right decision because not long after my husband was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. He had major surgery. If I had been going through chemo I don't know what we would have done! Sadly his cancer returnedvand he died early this year. I hang out in the pancreatic cancer and bereaved spouses group these days. Squeaky
Posts.Title: Oncotype results and should I have chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Candytop I was only alerted to this post a little earlier and not when you wrote it the other day. Carolyn's response is helpful. I looked at things another way perhaps. I didn't have exact figures but on because I had a small tumour and no lymph node involvement i had a good prognosis. The 4% is, i think, based on a cohort of women in the same situation and gives improvement rate of that amount generally - but maybe not for a particular individual. Statistics are useful but they cannot give a guarantee. I didn't spend long thinking about this because 4% didn't seem much to me. I don't try to persuade anyone not to have chemo but I do speak up to say I didn't so that people feel they can make choices. My two year check up has just taken place and currently there is no evidence of disease. But who knows about the future! Squeaky
Posts.Title: Oncotype results and should I have chemo?

Posts.Content: Ruthie I don't often join this group these days but I happened to notice your question. i was in the same situation as you with a 4% reduction if I had chemo. I decided not to have chemo. That was two years ago. I have no idea what will happen in the future but I don't regret the decision. Squeaky
Posts.Title: Oncotype results and should I have chemo?

Posts.Content: Carolyn I had read a book called 'Living with Dying'  by a Glasgow GP Margaret McCartney. She talks about the pressure people are under from family and friends to have further treatment that they don't really want to have. My husband and I agreed (this was before he was diagnosed) that in the event of a decision having to be made the person being offered the treatment would decide and neither of us would put pressure on the other. I keep busy. I am doing a masters degree in local history on the weaving industry in Dunfermline in the second half of the 19th century and I am very involved with Rotary. I live with three cats and at Christmas I am going to my husband's sailing pals family as we did for a number of years. As with you having breast cancer came as a bit of a surprise. I had a WLE but had to go back as the margins were not clear. Fortunately, it had not spread to the lymph nodes. Squeaky
Posts.Title: Oncotype results and should I have chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi It's AA Milne. It's probably a Winnie the Pooh quote. It starts off 'If ever there is a tomorrow when we are not together..' Squeaky
Posts.Title: Oncotype results and should I have chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Grey Bird, waiting for results is never easy and it is natural to worry. However, try to take one day at a time. You will get lots of support here. As chloecat says you can opt not to have treatments. I was borderline for having chemotherapy and decided not to have it but had radiotherapy with minimum side effects and am now on letrozole which is a hormone therapy similar to the one chloecat is taking. With that I have had minimum side effects but I know others have had joint pain and other things. When making decisions about treatment I thought about myself and my lifestyle and what I wanted to do. I didnt have DCIS. I had invasive cancer. I had to have a reexcision after the WLE as the tumour margins were not clear. This came as a surprise but I know know it's the case in about 20%. the surgeon said he had booked me in for the op in three days' time and I blurted out 'But I'm going to the theatre that day and i've got good seats. Assuming it was local and an evening performance the surgeon said he would have me out in time to go. As it was an afternoon performance 60 miles away I changed the tickets but I could easily have gone out that night after the second operation. I'm sure you will cope well with whatever happens next. Squeaky
Posts.Title: I didn't see this coming!

Posts.Content: Hi Nomad I see you are from Fife. So am I. It's a bit scary as you wait for results but you can be assured that you will get great treatment. Everything will happen very quickly and your treatment will be well planned. Let us know how you get on with your appointment.
Posts.Title: How long have you waited to have surgery after chemo?

Posts.Content: Thanks for posting. You are very inspiring.
Posts.Title: Getting Rid of Frustrations!

Posts.Content: Flower Thanks for starting this positive thread. It's still dark and I have just been outside where the sky is full of stars and way overhead was a plane probably bound for somewhere far away. Like you I thought of not worrying. As Heather says we can lose the enjoyment of the moment worrying about the future. I hope you are all enjoying this time of year. Squeaky
Posts.Title: I've Just Had A Brainwave!

Posts.Content: I cannot see why you shouldn't have gel nails when on letrozole. If you have had gel nails before you will know all about them. I had them for a while a few years ago. Your nails look lovely. But, in my view, it weakens your own nails. I have never had them again.
Posts.Title: Letrozole and gel nails

Posts.Content: Hi DEM A very interesting post. Please let us know how you get on speaking to oncologist. You have done some amazing research. best wishes Squeaky
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Catchpole I just wanted to reassure you that you will be able to cope with the wait for surgery. It was great your friend was with you when you got the call so that she could negotiate a date change. My lump wasn't in the same position as yours so can't comment but you are moving forward with dates set and your treatment plan beginning to take shape. I've seen a number of medics during treatment, some friendly, some less so! Just take one day at a time! Squeaky
Posts.Title: Saw Surgeon

Posts.Content: Hi Comper like you I can be claustrophobic. I had a scan before surgery and another after, each at different hospitals. On the second one they told me how long each of the parts of the examination would last and I counted the seconds. In the first one I had no idea how long either the whole examination would take or the how long each part would be and the only time anyone spoke to me through the intercom was when they told me they were injecting dye. The second was a far better experience as I was spoken to before each test. It might be a thought to ask them to do this, to reassure you! Only with one test did the NHS Scotland minutes last longer than mine but the counting took my mind off things!
Posts.Title: MRI

Posts.Content: Well done!
Posts.Title: MRI

Posts.Content: Hi Nomad, I had a lumpectomy so can't tell you about mastectomy as others can. However, I can reassure you that the cannula is fitted for the anaesthetic and next thing you are asleep. I had two surgeries as the first didn't have clear margins. The first surgery I was nervous about but the second I wasn't. My mother who lived a long life used to look at difficult situations as an adventure. The day I was diagnosed I turned into my Mother and decided this was an adventure. Perhaps I'd rather not have had it but it's here anyway. You'll be fine. We all get amazing strength from somewhere!
Posts.Title: Mastectomy and lymph nodes removed

Posts.Content: I saw the oncologist yesterday to 'sign me off' after all treatment. I mentioned I had some discomfort and he said that this often continued for a year or 18 months after surgery.
Posts.Title: Is this normal??

Posts.Content: I think the discomfort is from the nerve endings are healing so that gives discomfort. Yes, I see the point you are making Yvonne.
Posts.Title: Is this normal??

Posts.Content: I had the same pains. I think it is nerve ends healing. It went on quite a long time as I had two surgeries with second to clear margins. I have recently had radiotherapy and that has given me pains too!
Posts.Title: Boob pain after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Please don't be concerned that the hospital are not saying the stage of cancer. I don't think every hospital uses this measure. I wasn't told anything. Please don't worry. The hospital will not keep things from you. They will tell you everything. I can't comment on your treatment as a 44 year old as I am 20 years older but others will soon comment. Easier said than done but try not to worry.
Posts.Title: Just joined the roller coaster - help !

Posts.Content: Dreamthief, sorry to hear both of you are under the weather. For the first time, I had the flu jab this year. Hope you feel better soon. If the wind with you is anything like it is here in Scotland it'll blow the germs away. Squeaky
Posts.Title: G n j
